frameDefinitions: This frame has to do with people (the Residents) residing in Locations, sometimes with a Co-resident.
A concept, Concept_1, is related causally or collocationally to another concept, Concept_2 by means of some evidence.
Despite some implication that a State would be interrupted, the Entity remains in the specified State.
A Resisting_entity is capable of resisting or does resist a physical Opposing_force to a level specified by the target.
An Agent is performing the portion of an Activity in which there is dynamic stability. ''
An Agent supports their body in a particular Location.
frameExamples: The great and <t>impregnable</t> fortress still stands today.
Not noticing the hoards of people rushing by the window, Manny <t>continued</t> eating his lunch.
listRoleDefinitions: The individual(s) that reside at the <fen>Location</fen>.
The place in which somebody resides.
A person or group of people that the resident is staying with or among.
This role refers to the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Resident</fen> resides.
The concept which is linked to <fen>Concept_2</fen>.  Generally expressed as the external argument.
The concept which is tied to <fen>Concept_1</fen>.  Generally expressed as a PP complement.
The two concepts expressed jointly.
A concrete or abstract <fen>Entity</fen>.
The <fen>State</fen> of an <fen>Entity</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>State</fen> is found to still persist.
The location where the <fen>Entity</fen> is in the <fen>State</fen>.
The <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> is the item that resists the <fen>Opposing_force</fen> to the level specified by the target.

The <fen>Opposing_force</fen> is the item placed in opposition to the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen>. <fen>Opposing_force</fen> hinders, blocks, helps, or allows (lets) the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> to resist at the level specified by the target. Sometimes this Core role is incorporated in the target; otherwise, it is often null instantiated in example sentences.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> resists an external force.
The location where the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> resists an external force.

Duration denotes the length of <fen>Time</fen> from the beginning of a continuous situation (the one denoted by the target) to its end. In many cases, the continuous situation is a dynamic action which is ongoing, while in others it is simply an undifferentiated state.
This role identifies the name of the ongoing <fen>Activity</fen> in which an <fen>Agent</fen> engages.
The <fen>Agent</fen> engages in an ongoing <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when an ongoing <fen>Activity</fen> occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the ongoing <fen>Activity</fen> occurs.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the individual whose body is in a particular posture.  The <fen>Agent</fen> role is generally expressed as the external argument of verbs:
A description of the position of the <fen>Agent</fen>.  The <fen>Location</fen> of the <fen>Agent</fen> is frequently expressed and generally occurs as a PP Complement:
The part of the body that provides support to the <fen>Agent</fen>'s body in the posture.
This role indicates the Time interval during which the <fen>Agent</fen> held a certain posture.
listRoleExamples: Martial law remains in effect <fex>in Absurdistan</fex>.
These are made from a tough <fex>plastic foam</fex> and are very light to wear.
The fortress was impregnable <fex>to attack by hostile invaders</fex>.
The retaining wall was even weaker <fex>yesterday</fex>, and had begun to crumble.
They decided the tree-house would be sturdiest <fex>in the big old backyard oak</fex>.
I stood <fex>on my heels</fex> and looked out the window
<fex>Yesterday evening</fex> he was sitting in his armchair as usual
